references: In Table 1, we report the losses after the first stage of the algorithm, when 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} has been trained and 𝐃=0𝐃0\mathbf{D}=0, and the loss after the second stage of the algorithm when both 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} and 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D} have been trained. Figure 10 compares these two kernels, for c=0.0003𝑐0.0003c=0.0003 and δ=0.5𝛿0.5\delta=0.5, to illustrate that the two kernels are similar except for a small negative tail in the sign-changing kernel for large |y−x|/δ𝑦𝑥𝛿|y-x|/\delta. Nevertheless, Table 1 illustrates that by fitting a sign-changing kernel as opposed to a nonnegative kernel, an average loss decreases by 19% for δ=0.125𝛿0.125\delta=0.125, 44% for δ=0.25𝛿0.25\delta=0.25, 42% for δ=0.5𝛿0.5\delta=0.5, and 12% for δ=0.99𝛿0.99\delta=0.99.

Note that allowing non-positive kernels provides only a very small negative part near |y−x|=δ𝑦𝑥𝛿|y-x|=\delta, yet provides a substantial increase in accuracy (Tables 1 and 2).

references: To answer the question above, we first note that solutions to the Poisson problem for the truncated fractional Laplacian (obtained by simply truncating the domain of integration in (8.1)) approach solutions of the non-truncated counterpart asymptotically with order 𝒪​(δ−2​s)𝒪superscript𝛿2𝑠\mathcal{O}(\delta^{-2s}) [55]; this type of convergence holds in general for other instances of fractional operators such as the fractional gradient and divergence [56]. Thus, for very small horizons, e.g., for δ≈|Ω|𝛿Ω\delta\approx|\Omega|, we cannot expect solutions to the truncated equation to be accurate approximations of solutions to the non-truncated one. This fact can be observed in the last column of Table 3 where we report the relative difference, for different values of δ𝛿\delta between the non-truncated and truncated solutions; as expected, for very small δ𝛿\delta, the truncated solution is significantly different than the non-truncated one. These results are reported as a reference and their importance will be clear after we describe the impact of our algorithm.

using the trapezoidal quadrature rule,
where 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is the Green’s function [55].
We train with 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} in (4.13) consisting of 161 equidistant points in [−0.8,0.8]0.80.8[-0.8,0.8] to avoid singularities of the solutions uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} near the boundary points −11-1 and 111 [57].
We test our algorithm for several values of δ𝛿\delta and various order M𝑀M of the basis, initializing α𝛼\alpha to be 00. In Table 3 we report the relative difference between the test solution for forcing f=1𝑓1f=1 and fractional order s=0.75𝑠0.75s=0.75 and the solution obtained by solving the nonlocal problem (2.2) with kernel K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}. While a higher order does not necessarily yield a better prediction, for higher values of δ𝛿\delta, as expected, we obtain a much better approximation. As a reference we also report the difference that one would obtain by simply truncating the kernel (8.2). These results show that it is possible to obtain relatively accurate solutions to fractional equations at a much cheaper cost by using compactly supported fractional-type kernels learned from fractional data.
